Nick_13:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{For|the album|Nick 13 (album){{!}}''Nick 13'' (album)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Nick 13 | image = Nick_13.jpg | caption = Nick 13 playing at Warped Tour in 2007. | image_size = | background = solo_singer | occupation = Musician, singer-songwriter, lyricist, vocalist, guitarist | instrument = Vocals, guitar, piano | genre = {{Hlist|[[Alternative country]]{{cite web |url= https://verbicidemagazine.com/2011/08/15/nick-13-st/|title=NICK 13 – S/T |last= Edmund|first=Matt |date= August 15, 2011 |work=Verbicide Magazine |access-date=2023-08-10 |quote=Mark my words, Nick 13 will become a heavy hitter in the alternative country arena if he continues down this solo path.}}|[[psychobilly]]}} | origin = [[Ukiah, California|Ukiah]], California, U.S. | associated_acts = [[Tiger Army]], [[AFI (band)|AFI]] }} '''Kearney Nick Jones''', better known by his stage name '''Nick 13''', is the lead vocalist, guitarist and main songwriter of [[psychobilly]] band [[Tiger Army]], as well as a solo artist in the [[alternative country]] genre. ==Career== ===Tiger Army=== {{main|Tiger Army}} Tiger Army was signed to [[Hellcat Records]] in 1996 shortly after forming and released their [[Tiger Army (album)|self-titled]] full-length debut album in October 1999. That album was followed by 2001's ''[[Tiger Army II: Power of Moonlite]]'', 2004's ''[[Tiger Army III: Ghost Tigers Rise]]'' and 2007's ''[[Music from Regions Beyond]]'' before leaving the label. Their latest album, ''[[V •••–]]'', was released in 2016 on [[Luna Tone Records]]/[[Rise Records]]. ===Solo career=== In an interview, Nick 13 was asked why the sole songwriter for a band would launch a solo career.{{cite news|url=http://www.altpress.com/features/entry/qa_nick_13_on_tiger_armys_14th_anniversary/|title=Nick 13 On Tiger Army's 14th Anniversary |date=April 7, 2010|accessdate=December 14, 2010 | work=Alternative Press}} "The first person to give me the idea of a primary songwriter making a solo record was Paul Fenech of [[The Meteors]]," he said. "I always thought there was something cool about that: You write all the songs for the band, and there's a certain sound people expect. But while Tiger Army has always tested those kinds of boundaries, there are certain things that relate to heaviness and aggression that aren't part of my solo project, at all." When asked about the status of Tiger Army, he said, "Tiger Army aren't going anywhere—we will be back." His first full performance as a solo artist was at the [[Stagecoach Festival]] in Indio, California, in spring, 2010, where he opened for [[Merle Haggard]] and [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]]. A handful of small club dates in California followed, leading up to an appearance at the Hootenanny Festival in Orange County just before [[Chuck Berry]]. Press reviews for both festival events were favorable.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.inlandsocal.com/music/2010/04/stagecoach-nick-13-trades-punk.html|title=Stagecoach Nick 13 Trades Punk for Country|date=April 24, 2010|accessdate=December 14, 2010|work=The Press Enterprise|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713035137/http://blogs.inlandsocal.com/music/2010/04/stagecoach-nick-13-trades-punk.html|archivedate=July 13, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/rock-80491-ocprint-berry-material.html|title=Hootenanny Still Strong |date=July 5, 2010|accessdate=December 14, 2010 | work=OC Register}} Nick revealed in an interview with ''No Depression'' that he had recorded with a wide-ranging group of notable musicians including [[Greg Leisz]], [[Eddie Perez (guitarist)|Eddie Perez]], [[Lloyd Green]], Joshua Grange, and [[Mitch Marine]].{{cite news|url=http://www.theocgazette.com/GazetteMagazine/OC_Gazette_Nick13.html|title=Tiger Army's Nick 13|date=July 21, 2010|accessdate=December 14, 2010|work=No Depression|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717020344/http://www.theocgazette.com/GazetteMagazine/OC_Gazette_Nick13.html|archive-date=July 17, 2011|url-status=dead}} According to Nick's official [[Twitter]] page updates, album work continued as of December 2010.{{cite news|url=https://twitter.com/nick13official|title=Nick 13 official page |accessdate=December 14, 2010 | work=Twitter}} The album was co-produced by Greg Leisz and James Intveld. Following Nick's performance at South By Southwest, [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] announced that they would be releasing Nick's debut solo album on June 7, 2011.{{cite news|url=http://sugarhillrecords.com/artists.html?controller=artists&task=view&id=196|title=Nick 13 Sugar Hill Records |date=April 22, 2011|accessdate=April 22, 2011 | work=Sugar Hill Records}} He kicked off touring in support of the album with two nights at [[Troubadour (West Hollywood, California)|The Troubadour]] in West Hollywood, followed by national touring through October 2011. The album has been very well received by the Americana press.{{cite news|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/nick-13-nick-13l|title=No Depression Blog Review|date=August 20, 2011|accessdate=August 25, 2011|work=No Depression}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Nick's road support of the album included an appearance at [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]].{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2011/05/austin_city_lim_5.html|title=Austin City Limits 2011 Festival Line-Up Is Here |date=May 17, 2011 |accessdate=May 16, 2012 | work=Brooklyn Vegan}} Nick made several appearance's on Nashville's [[WSM (AM)|WSM]] Radio in November 2011, including a performance at Americana Carnival.{{cite news |url=http://nashville.getoutbeactive.com/event/nick-13-wsm-americana-carnival/ |title=Nick 13 @ Americana Carnival |date=November 13, 2011 |accessdate=May 16, 2012 |work=Nashville: Get Out Be Active |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120710101808/http://nashville.getoutbeactive.com/event/nick-13-wsm-americana-carnival/ |archivedate=July 10, 2012 }} [[Great American Country]] added the video for "All Alone" to their "Out of the Box" program in December 2011 and has continued to air it throughout 2012.{{cite news|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6041225,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930013835/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_6041225,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 30, 2011|title=Nick 13 Biography on GAC|date=December 1, 2011|accessdate=May 16, 2012|work=Great American Country website}} In January 2012, Nick appeared at the [[NAMM Show]] where he performed and met with fans at the booth operated by [[Gretsch]], his guitar endorser.{{cite news |url=http://gretschpages.com/happenings/winter-namm-2012/updates/132/ |title=Nick 13: Live Saturday Set |date=January 24, 2012 |accessdate=May 16, 2012 |work=Gretsch Pages |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311054024/http://gretschpages.com/happenings/winter-namm-2012/updates/132/ |archivedate=March 11, 2013 }} In the summer of 2012, Nick headlined two nights at the [[El Rey Theatre (Los Angeles)|El Rey Theatre]] in Hollywood and released a music video for "Carry My Body Down." The video for "Carry My Body Down" began airing on [[Great American Country]]'s "Out of the Box" program and on [[Country Music Television]] in late summer, 2012. The video reached No. 1 on CMT Pure's "12-Pack Countdown" in November 2012.{{cite news|url=http://nick13.tumblr.com/post/34878133748/1-thank-you-my-video-hit-number-one-on-thisl|title=Nick 13 Tumblr |date=November 2012|accessdate=November 17, 2012 }} Nick appeared at the 2013 Stagecoach Festival with [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Marty Stuart]] and more, broadcast on AXS TV. The video for "Nighttime Sky" arrived around the same time, eventually debuting at No. 1 on CMT Pure's "12-Pack Countdown" and staying there for 6 consecutive weeks. Nick tweeted plans to shoot and direct a fourth video himself, for the track "In the Orchard."{{cite news|url=https://twitter.com/nick13/status/406844537940631552|title=Nick 13 Tumblr |date=November 2013|accessdate=December 9, 2013 | work=Nick 13 Twitter}} This video was released in July 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.cmtedge.com/2014/07/31/nick-13-strolls-down-memory-lane-in-the-orchard/|title=CMT Edge |date=July 2014|accessdate=July 31, 2014 }} According to his official Twitter account, Nick intends to write and record a second solo album before creating a new Tiger Army album.{{cite news|url=https://twitter.com/Nick13Official/status/245569990823116800l|title=Nick 13 Twitter|date=September 11, 2012|accessdate=November 17, 2012 }} Nick 13 is a practitioner of [[Transcendental Meditation]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/an-interview-with-nick-13|title=An Interview with Nick 13|date=August 26, 2010|accessdate=December 14, 2010|work=No Depression|archive-date=July 16, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716182502/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/an-interview-with-nick-13|url-status=dead}} Nick has stated that he does not mix politics with music, but has criticized [[George W. Bush]] and the [[Christian right|religious right]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.skruttmagazine.se/tigerarmy2004eng.htm|title=For the second time Nick 13 from Tiger Army answers some questions from me|website=Skruttmagazine.se|accessdate=September 17, 2020}} ==Discography== {{Main|Tiger Army#Discography}} ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Details ! colspan="5"| Peak chart positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="40"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]
